sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: If a set A contains 4 elements, what is the size of its power set and how does this compare to the size of set A itself?
message_2:
The size of a power set is determined by the number of subsets a set has, including the empty set and the set itself. For a set A with n elements, the size of its power set is 2^n.

In this case, set A contains 4 elements, so the size of its power set is 2^4, which equals 16.

Comparing the size of the power set to the size of set A itself, we see that the power set is significantly larger. Set A has 4 elements, while its power set has 16 elements.
